Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was very knowledgeable about the topic and always available to answer any questions. He was a great teaching assistant!
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Muehleisen, Andrew

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  He was an effective tutor and grader. I can't think of any areas for improvement.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew is very accessible, responsive, and patient. Overall a fantastic TA.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was super helpful at de-bugging code and explained concepts really clearly!
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was terrific. He was very good at explaining the concepts and quickly responded to emails and made plenty of office hour time available.

Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was an amazing TA, I would not have gotten nearly as much out of this course as I did without him. We was very good about always making himself available and answering emails right away. He clearly has a grasp on the material and is great at communicating complex ideas/concepts to students. Nothing to improve on, thanks andrew!!!
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Very knowledgeable of the material and capable of answering student questions.
Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  Andrew was great -- very accessible and helpful!

Instructor: Andrew John Muehleisen  What a wonderful man and educator. Patient. Prompt. Gracious. Polite. Learned. Understanding of where and how R can be difficult. Andrew was always there to inform, answer, encourage.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think it would be helpful to restructure the way the class was taught. The online notes for each section were very helpful, but I didn't get much from your going over them in class. I did learn lot when I actually had to use the notes and do examples and problem sets. This class might be a good opportunity for a flipped class; you could create videos of each topic where you go over the notes online, and show us the basics. Then, in class, we would do sample problems and get more hands-on, guided experience. I think the homework assignments and mid-terms were very useful, but there wasn't enough of it (at least in the beginning of the semester).
Instructor can be difficult to understand. It would help to improve on the basics of public speaking and engaging the students.
Simon needs to be deliberate about speaking more loudly and clearly.
A very good course to add to and reinforce R skills!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The quizzes, because they made me sit down and actually use R
Hands-on work and getting help to answer questions.

Having time in class to work on exercises, homework assignments, etc. was very helpful because it gave students the opportunity to ask questions immediately when we were having trouble with a concept or problem.
If you have indpedent research this is an amazing course. I go so much out of homework assigments and can say that my comprehension of the material really increased drastically throughout the course.
Semi-weekly quizzes were really valuable in providing the hands-on experience necessary to learn the material.

Simon's web-page is very well put together. I really liked being able to work through the pages before class so that we could answer questions or go into a little more depth in class. It was also very useful to refer back to the web-pages later during homework assignments, or when working with my won data. The homework was great at synthesizing the concepts and solidifying the code in my mind.

R is really useful -- I already found myself using it in other courses. The class was helpful in forcing me to actually learn the program; while there are free resources online, this class actually gave me motivation to follow through on learning (rather than procrastinating forever, which is what would have likely happened otherwise). Also, Simon's notes on his website have been extremely helpful.
Hands-on. Good pace to the tests and quizzes. Good topics. Great instructors.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The lectures were a bit weak
Instructor presenting. It would be nice to focus a bit more on indexing when that topic is covered at the beginning of the course.

I feel like the pace of the course could be improved...perhaps the beginning lectures could move faster, and more time could be dedicated to statistics, special topics in R programming, etc. I felt like we moved very slowly though the first portion of the class and too quickly through the last.
It would be lovely if we actually received grades or feedback on the midterm. It's the end of the course and have not received.

Assignments should be posted earlier, I felt like I was penalized for starting assignments too early because they would often change by the end of the week meaning more work just because I had started early.

The pace of the course was a bit slow. Not a lot of ground was covered in a semester's worth of lectures. Too much class time was devoted to doing homework and quizzes, which could have been done on students' personal time, as the workload for the course was fairly light.

I found it pretty easy to excel at this course. I think it is important to note here that prior to this I had no experience with programming, had been out of school for 8 years, and considered myself a bit of a Luddite. While it was very gratifying to do so well on my homework and mid-term assignments, I probably could have benefited from a slightly accelerated pace--or a few more concepts per week. That being said, I learned so much and I feel confident moving forward with continuing to learn R on my own.

The semi-flipped structure of the class didn't work especially well for me personally; it was especially difficult to focus/hear when Simon would be lecturing at the front of the room while Andrew helped students with questions in the back. Again, I really appreciated having Andrew available for such help, but having a second running discussion in such a tight space was very distracting.
Try to get in more of the foundation material in class and with some warm-up exercises. If one misses material at the beginning, it is difficult to catch up.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I am already using the skills that I learned in this class for multiple research projects, and wouldn't have been able to do certain analyses without it.
Very helpful course.
Very valuable information for anyone doing statistical analysis
Super relevant, every research degree should take this course!!!!
Learning how to code and conduct statistical analyses is important for the geospatial work I'm currently doing.

I will be using R extensively to analyze my data, create graphics, and for modeling of my study system. It is critical that I have a firm grasp of how to manipulate the program to effectively and efficiently perform the functions I need, and I am grateful that I was able to take this course during my first semester at FES so that I may use what I learned throughout the rest of my master's program!
It fit well. I wish I had been able to take it or audit it my first semester here.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I need R to analyze my data and do my research
To learn how to use R.
To learn more about R and how I can use it in my research in the coming years.
To enhance my reserach
relevant to my research
Having a working knowledge of R will be greatly beneficial in conducting statistical analyses for my research in the future.
As I've been considering PhD programs and looking at job postings, additional ability in statistics in general and using R in particular seemed like it would be useful.
I struggled using R in other classes.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes; I learned a lot and can use those skills in my own work.
Yes.
Yes, I now am able to use R and effectively analyze data.
Yes. Incredible difference in my knowledge and abilities from the start to the end of the semester.
Yes- I think I learned enough about R to be able to use it effectively (at least at a basic level) in my work.
Yes. But I think it would be helpful to offer a class that incorporated statistics and programming. We need a 4 credit class called "Intro to R and environmental statistics" or something like that.

Yes, I didn't hate this course nearly as much as I expected to, R is a frustrating program to learn and I'm sure and even more frustrating program to teach. I can honestly say I feel a command over the material beyond my expectations going into the course.
The pace of the course was a bit slow and more material should have been covered.

Yes. I hoped to become proficient at running R code and informed as to where and how to seek resources for functions/code I do not understand, and I have. By the end of the semester, I was pleased to be manipulating my own data with ease--and pleased that patterns of how R interfaces with data are now intuitive to me (whereas they seemed awkward at the beginning of the semester for someone who had previously only worked with spreadsheets).
Yes
About 98%

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Don't get behind, and practice as much as you can.
I would highly recommend this course for anyone who is interested in learning the programming language of R.
Take the course if you need advanced statistics, don't take the course otherwise.
Take the course early in your time at FES if you plan to take any R-heavy courses like Conservation Science or Regression Modeling during your time here.
If you work through the web-pages and assignments, and take advantage of Simon as a resource in and out of class, you will become a R-Wizard!
Take it!
